speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Georgina
text: And I’m Georgina.

speaker: Neil
text: Do you believe in ghosts, Georgina?

speaker: Georgina
text: Well, I’ve never actually seen one - not even at Halloween.

speaker: Neil
text: How about dragons then? Or fairies and elves?

speaker: Georgina
text: Have you been reading fantasy books, Neil? Lord of the Rings?

speaker: amphibious
text: I have been reading a book, Georgina, but not Lord of the Rings. My book is about an amphibious creature – a creature that lives both on land and in water.

speaker: Georgina
text: Some kind of Frog-Man?

speaker: Neil
text: You’ve almost got the idea, Georgina, but think - woman, not man; and fish, not frog.

speaker: Georgina
text: Half-woman, half-fish? I’ve got it – a mermaid!

speaker: Neil
text: That’s right! Mermaids are magical creatures, half-woman, half-fish, that feature in the myths and legends of many cultures around the world.

speaker: Georgina
text: Like the Sirens, whose seductive singing shipwrecked Odysseus and his sailors in ancient Greek mythology.

speaker: Neil
text: The Sirens are perhaps the most famous, but certainly not the only, mermaids we’ll be hearing about. But before we dive into the programme, it’s time for my quiz question. The book I’ve been reading was, of course, The Little Mermaid.

speaker: Georgina
text: Yes, I’ve seen the Disney movie. The mermaid is called Ariel.

speaker: Neil
text: Right – but the movie was based on a fairy tale written by Hans Christian Andersen. It became so famous that a statue of the Little Mermaid was built in the harbour of Andersen’s birthplace – but where? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Amsterdam,

speaker: Neil
text: b) Copenhagen, or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Oslo?

speaker: Georgina
text: I’m going to say b) Copenhagen.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Georgina, I’ll tell you the answer later. Disney’s defenceless mermaid, Ariel, seems the total opposite to the seductive, dangerous Sirens in the Odyssey. In fact, descriptions and stories of mermaids have always changed from place to place.

speaker: Georgina
text: One mermaid-like character found across Africa and the Americas is named, Mami Wata. Here’s British writer, Marcelle Mateki, talking about the origins of this legend to BBC World Service programme, The Forum:

speaker: pidgin English loosely translateddeity
text: Even the name, Mami Wata, which is pidgin English for ‘Mother Water’, so it’s loosely translated from pidgin English as ‘the mother of water’ and the characteristics that are commonly shared when speaking about Mami Wata across the West African coast is that this deity is the protector of the water kingdom.

speaker: pidgin English
text: The name ‘Mami Wata’ comes from Nigerian pidgin English – a language which has developed from a mixture of two languages and is used as a way of communicating by people who do not speak each other’s languages.

speaker: loosely translated –
text: Marcelle says that ‘Mami Wata’ means ‘the mother of water’ when loosely translated – translated in a way that carries over the basic ideas but using words which may not be so accurate.

speaker: deity
text: Mami Wata is also described as the protector of the water kingdom and a deity – a god, goddess or other divine being.

speaker: Georgina
text: Another version of a mermaid-like creatures, called Selkies, are found in the remote Orkney Islands, north of the Scottish mainland. The Selkies can take human form and marry men but every now and then they return to their watery kingdom under the sea.

speaker: Neil
text: Cristina Bacchilega is co-editor of The Penguin Book of Mermaids. According to her, these different versions of mermaids share something in common - they force us to question our relationship to water and other beings in the natural world – and even to question how we see ourselves.

speaker: Georgina
text: Here’s Cristina explaining more in the BBC World Service’s, The Forum:

speaker: shape-shiftershumility
text: The beings, not just mermaids but Selkies and water deities and other water spirits are often shape-shifters, they have a certain kind of fluidity of being… So do we approach this world with humility, or do we really uphold a kind of anthropocentric view, human-centred view of life?

speaker: shape-shifters
text: Mythical creatures are often shape-shifters – they have the power to change into a different shape or form.

speaker: humility
text: Moving between the sea and the Earth, mermaids link two natural worlds. Cristina thinks that, as humans, we should approach them with humility.

speaker: humility is
text: Someone who has humility is not proud and doesn’t think they are better than others.

speaker: Georgina
text: Well, Neil, I don’t think I’m better than a ghost, a water spirit or a mermaid – it’s just that I've never seen one. But then again, I’ve never seen electricity – and I believe in that!

speaker: Neil
text: Maybe it would help if you saw a statue of a mermaid, if not the real thing?

speaker: Georgina
text: Maybe – but where would I find one?

speaker: Neil
text: In my quiz question I asked where you’d see the statue of Hans Christian Andersen’s Little Mermaid. What did you say, Georgina?

speaker: Georgina
text: I guessed b) Copenhagen.

speaker: Neil
text: Which was… the correct answer! The Little Mermaid statue is found in Andersen’s birthplace of Copenhagen. And it really is little – only 1.25m high!

speaker: amphibious
text: In this programme, we’ve been talking about mermaids – mythical half-woman, half-fish creatures which are amphibious – live both on land and in water.

speaker: deities shape-shifters -
text: In some cultures, mermaids are deities – or goddesses. They can also be shape-shifters - imaginary creatures with the power to change into different shapes.

speaker: pidgin English -
text: One African mermaid is called, Mami Wata, in pidgin English - amixture of English and local languages which enables people who do not share a common language to communicate.

speaker: loose translation –
text: Mami Wata means ‘Mother Water’ – but this is a loose translation – a translation which carries over the basic idea but using words which may not be so accurate.

speaker: Georgina
text: That’s all for this programme, but the next time you’re near the sea, keep an eye out for a splash in the waves – you never know what you might see!

speaker: Neil
text: Join us again soon for more discussion and vocabulary here at 6 Minute English. And follow us on social media. Bye for now!

speaker: Georgina
text: Bye!
